Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial on Negative-Pressure Wound Therapy in Stoma-Reversal Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: single-centre, open-label, parallel, individually randomised controlled trial

Participants.evidence: Patients scheduled for elective stoma-reversal surgery were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised (1:1) to receive NPWT or conventional wound dressing

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether negative-pressure wound therapy (NPWT) improves wound healing compared with conventional wound dressing.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of wound complications and SSIs within 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between June 2019 and January 2021, 100 patients were randomised: 50 to NPWT (49 analysed) and 50 to control (45 analysed).

Number_Analysed.evidence: 50 to NPWT (49 analysed) and 50 to control (45 analysed).

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference was found in wound-complication rate (10% NPWT vs. 16% control; odds ratio 0.61, 95% CI 0.18 to 2.10, P = 0.542)
